titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Publications (Non-Grant Related), Accessions 2017:079 and 2017:089
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Publications (Non-Grant Related), Accessions 2017:079 and 2017:089 FA1394
titlestmt.author: Katie Martin

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2018-02-22 00:03:53 -0500.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Publications (Non-Grant Related), Accessions 2017:079 and 2017:089

physdesc.extent:
24 boxes
(13 letter document containers, 6 legal document containers, 4 oversize containers, and 1 half-legal document container)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ford Foundation records, Publications (Non-Grant Related), Accessions 2017:079 and 2017:089 houses publication files of the Office of Communications' Art and Design Unit. Documents within the collection include proofs, correspondence, drafts, memoranda, licensing agreements, typesetting specifications, distribution files, and final versions of annual reports, quarterly reports, and various other reports published by the Ford Foundation between 1973 and 1998.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Original photographs from the 1991 and 1992 Annual Reports can be found in Ford Foundation records, Multimedia Material, Accession 2017:067

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: This material was transferred to RAC in 2017 by the Ford Foundation and ingested by RAC as Accession 2017:079 and Accession 2017:089.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Ford Foundation was chartered by Henry and Edsel Ford in 1936 "to receive and administer funds for scientific, educational and charitable purposes, all for the public welfare", and initially served the Ford family's charitable interests in the Detroit area. Following the deaths of Edsel Ford (1943) and Henry Ford (1947), the Foundation was propelled to the forefront of philanthropy as the largest American foundation in terms of both endowment and yearly expenditures, and with an international scope to its major program areas.

During the Foundation's first twenty years its major programs were in international economic development, primary and higher education, educational and public broadcasting, behavioral sciences, civil liberties, urban development, fine arts and the humanities. The Ford Foundation also partnered with the Rockefeller Foundation in supporting agricultural development in South America, Africa, and Southeast Asia. Since the 1970s, the Foundation has also pioneered programs in women's rights, energy policy, micro-financing in under-developed countries, establishing human rights groups, and improving international HIV/AIDS education.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted (Boxes 21-24 contain confidental material). Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged into one series: Publications - Working Files
